. Physician wrote a Radiology report that says: [**2191-3-17**] 10:35 PM
 CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST; CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST                     Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 54512**]
 Reason: WEAKNESS, JAUNDICE
 Field of view: 36 Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  39 year old man with ascending weakness, jaundice, thrush and nausea vomiting
  for the last few days, lactate of 13
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  please eval with IV contrast only for acute process intraabdominal process
 No contraindications for IV contrast
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 WET READ: ARHb FRI [**2191-3-18**] 12:17 AM
  Diffuse esophageal wall thickening consistent with esophagitis. Appendix
  measures up to 8mm and appears indistinct- any evidence for acute
  appendicitis? Hypoattenuating liver may represent fatty infiltration A few
  small hypoattenuating hepatic lesions are of unclear etiology. Trace free
  fluid.

 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  39-year-old male with jaundice and ascending weakness, and nausea
 with vomiting.

 COMPARISON:  None.

 TECHNIQUE:  Contrast-enhanced axial images of the abdomen and pelvis were
 obtained with multiplanar reformatted images.

 CT ABDOMEN WITH CONTRAST:  The lung bases are unremarkable, and there is no
 pericardial or pleural effusion. Marked concentric wall thickening of the
 fluid filled esophagus is partially imaged.

 Diffuse hypoattenuation of the liver is consistent with fatty infiltration.  A
 10 mm hypodensity in segment V (2:26) has attenuation characteristics
 consistent with a cyst.  A cluster of smaller hypodensities near the dome
 (2:4) are too small to characterize.  The spleen, pancreas, adrenal glands
 appear normal. Hyperdense material within the gallbladder likely represents
 sludge. The kidneys enhance symmetrically and excrete contrast normally
 without hydronephrosis or hydroureter.  The stomach and intra- abdominal loops
 of large and small bowel are of normal caliber, and there is no obstruction.
 Scattered mesenteric and retroperitoneal lymph nodes are identified, none of
 which meet CT criteria for pathologic enlargement. The abdominal aorta is of
 normal caliber.  There is no free air. Small amounts of free fluid in the
 paracolic gutters and mesenteric edema represent third spacing.

 CT PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:  The rectum, sigmoid colon, and prostate are
 unremarkable.  The bladder contains a Foley and is decompressed.  A small
 amount of retropubic free fluid is noted.

 Bone windows reveal no worrisome lytic or sclerotic lesions.

 IMPRESSION:
                                                             (Over)

 [**2191-3-17**] 10:35 PM
 CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST; CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST                     Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 54512**]
 Reason: WEAKNESS, JAUNDICE
 Field of view: 36 Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 1.  Esophageal wall thickening consistent with esophagitis. Given the history,
 this is most consistent with [**Female First Name (un) **] esophagitis.

 2.  Fattly liver with at least one cyst. Smaller hypoattenuating lesions at
 the dome are too small to characterize.

 3.  Small amounts of free fluid with third-spacing.

 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Weakness.

 COMPARISON:  None.

 TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast head CT.

 FINDINGS:  There is no intracranial hemorrhage.  There is no mass, mass

. Physician wrote a Echo report that says: PATIENT/TEST INFORMATION:
Indication: CMP with hypotension
Height: (in) 73
Weight (lb): 140
BSA (m2): 1.85 m2
BP (mm Hg): 97/37
HR (bpm): 129
Status: Inpatient
Date/Time: [**2191-3-18**] at 11:06
Test: Portable TTE (Complete)
Doppler: Full Doppler and color Doppler
Contrast: None
Technical Quality: Adequate


INTERPRETATION:

Findings:

LEFT ATRIUM: Elongated LA.

RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Mildly dilated RA.

LEFT VENTRICLE: Normal LV wall thickness. Mildly dilated LV cavity. Normal
regional LV systolic function. Overall normal LVEF (>55%). TDI E/e' < 8,
suggesting normal PCWP (<12mmHg). No resting LVOT gradient.

RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion.

AORTA: Normal diameter of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels.

AORTIC VALVE: Normal aortic valve leaflets (3). No valvular AS. The increased
transaortic velocity is related to high cardiac output. No AR.

MITRAL VALVE: Normal mitral valve leaflets with trivial MR.

TRICUSPID VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets with trivial TR. Normal PA
systolic pressure.

PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: Normal pulmonic valve leaflet. No PS.
Physiologic PR.

PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion.

GENERAL COMMENTS: Resting tachycardia (HR>100bpm).

Conclusions:
The left atrium is elongated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal.
The left ventricular cavity is mildly dilated. Regional left ventricular wall
motion appears normal, but cannot be definitely excluded given the patient's
current tachycardia. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal
(LVEF>55%). Tissue Doppler imaging suggests a normal left ventricular filling
pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion
are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are
normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good
leaflet excursion. There is no valvular aortic stenosis. The increased
transaortic velocity is likely related to high cardiac output. No aortic
regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with
trivial mitral regurgitation. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure
is normal. There is no pericardial effusion.

IMPRESSION: Mildly dilated left ventricular cavity with vigorous global
systolic function and high cardiac output. No significant valvular disease or
pulmonary hypertension.

Findings consistent with a generalized high-output state (early sepsis,
anemia, thyrotoxicosis, peripheral AV shunting, beri-beri, etc.). If
clinically indicated, would recommend repeating the study when the patient is
less tachycardic.


. Physician wrote a Physician  report that says: TITLE: Attending note
   39 year-old man with heavy alcohol intake x 25 yrs, presented with
   profound weakness that began in [**Month (only) 2139**]-[**2191-1-3**] but much worse
   over past  2-4 weeks. Brought to ED yesterday for near paralysis and
   was found to have metabolic derangements and quadraparesis bordering on
   quadriplegia, as described in resident
s note and other notes above.
   His LE problems began with progressive edema. Has had care at [**Hospital1 5757**], and also told me that he was told his Na was low and
   K was high in the past.
   Key issues:
     * Has been treated with thiamine and his extremity strength has
       dramatically improved- now able to raise arms and legs against
       gravity and very weakly against some resistance
     * Lactic acidosis, which is characteristic of thiamine deficiency,
       improving, now 13
 3 and bicarb 8
     * Likely refeeding syndrome, phos 2.9
 0.5
 1.8, aggressively
       repleting Phos and Mg
     * Profound hypoalbuminemia at 2.2
     * Hypovolemic hyponatremia improving Na 120
 129
     * This afternoon became febrile and delirious. Likely EtOH
       withdrawal. Unclear when was last drink
EtOH on arrival 110, but pt
       says 4d ago, unreliable hx. Received valium 5mg x 2 with
       improvement in dysarthria.
     * Severe coagulopathy and concern for DIC, monitoring.
     * Pancultured, CXR unconcerning for pna, on vanc/zosyn and will have
       low threshold for LP if worsens. No leukocytosis.
     * I am concerned about resp status given new use of accessory
       muscles, though I think this may be from sepsis or alc withdrawal.
       Obtained VC 1900 and NIV -20. Will repeat q 4h or more if nec, and
       will check ABG as indicated.
   Critically ill
   90 minutes

 this is a possible diagnosis since there is significant
   improvement in weakness in just a few hours after large thiamine
   administration and the patient is nutritionally deficient. Found case
   reports of the neurological weakness as in this case resembling
   gullian-[**Location (un) **] syndrome. ([1]Koike H, [2]Ito S, [3]Morozumi S,

 syndrome in
   beriberi neuropathy: two case reports.)  Beriberi would also explain
   the extremely high lactic acidosis that paradoxically rose in setting
   of fluid resuscitation.
   Hyponatremia: no ascites on exam to suggest cirrhois and portal
   hypertension.  Also patient not overloaded on exam to suggest
   hypervolemic hyponatremia.  Initial thought is hypovolemic hyponatremia
   given relative hypotension and tachycardia.
   - Bolus with D5NS and recheck lytes.
   - Urine electrolytes
   AG Metabolic Acidosis: starvation ketosis with lactic acidosis with
   compensated pH. liver disease and alcoholism can lead to a decreased
   utilization of lactic acidosis.
   - Replete with D5 NS
   - calculated osmoles: 268
   - measures osmoles: 280
   - serum tox & utox negative
   - Trend lytes q2h until gap closes
   Weakness: 3 months of progressive weakness in the setting of alcohol
   use raises the possibility of a nutritional deficiency.  Patient's
   thiamine ordered for concern of Thiamine deficiency.
   - Neurology consult
   Coagulopathy: likely due to liver failure and poor nutrition. DIC also
   a possibility.
   - DIC labs pending
   - FFP for procedures
   - Trend
   Elevated Lipase: could be from subclinical alcoholic pancreatitis.
   - Will follow
   Hypoglycemia: impaired hepatic gluconeogeneis in setting background of
   poor nutrition.
   - replete with oral and IV repletion of glucise
   - ADAT

   Mild Hepatitis: Best etiology appears to be mild alcoholic hepatitis.
   Other differential includes viral, drug mediated, vascular, autoimmine,
   or Wilsons.   His transminitis isn't too impressive for toxin mediated,
   viral, or vascular pathologies.  Hepatomegaly without splenomegaly
   suggests early liver disease in acute exacerbation in the setting of

   level 110.
   - Viral serologies pending
   - Autoimmune studies pending
   - Ceruloplasmin
   - Social Work Consult
   - Nutrition Consult
   Dry Beriberi
 this is a possible diagnosis since there is significant
   improvement in weakness in just a few
   hours after large thiamine administration and the patient is
   nutritionally deficient.
   Found case reports of the neurological weakness as in this case
   resembling gullian-[**Location (un) **] syndrome.
   ([1]Koike H, [2]Ito S, [3]Morozumi S, [4]Kawagashira Y, [5]Iijima M,
   [6][**Last Name (un) 5736**] N, [7][**Doctor Last Name 5737**] F, [8]Sobue G.
   Rapidly developing weakness mimicking Guillain-[**Doctor Last Name **]
 syndrome in
   beriberi neuropathy: two case reports.)
    Beriberi would also explain the extremely high lactic acidosis that
   paradoxically rose in setting of fluid resuscitation.
   This would also explain the patient
s primary metabolic acidosis and
   primary respiratory alkalosis.
    ([9][**Doctor Last Name 1526**] MW, [10][**Doctor First Name 612**] J, [11][**Doctor Last Name 1226**] AJ, [12][**Last Name (un) 5746**] E, [13][**Doctor Last Name 3698**]
   M.
   Distinctive acid-base pattern in Wernicke's encephalopathy. [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 5747**]
   Med. [**2189**] [**Month (only) **];50(6):722-5. Epub [**2188**] [**1-6**].
   Hyponatremia: no ascites on exam to suggest cirrhois and portal
   hypertension.  Also patient not overloaded on exam to suggest
   hypervolemic hyponatremia.  Initial thought is hypovolemic hyponatremia
   given relative hypotension and tachycardia vs. euvolumic hyponatremia
   caused by beer potomania. Urine electrolytes are consistent with a low

 given the rapid onset, appears to be caused by

   ====
   Mild Hepatitis: Best etiology appears to be mild alcoholic hepatitis.
   Other differential includes viral, drug mediated, vascular, autoimmine,
   or Wilsons.   His transminitis isn't too impressive for toxin mediated,
   viral, or vascular pathologies.  Hepatomegaly without splenomegaly
   suggests early liver disease in acute exacerbation in the setting of
   EtOH. CT suggestive of fatty infiltration. Tox screen negative, EtOH
   level 110.
   - Viral serologies pending

   - Ceruloplasmin
   - Social Work Consult
   - Nutrition Consult
   Dry Beriberi
 this is a possible diagnosis since there is significant
   improvement in weakness in just a few
   hours after large thiamine administration and the patient is
   nutritionally deficient.
   Found case reports of the neurological weakness as in this case
   resembling gullian-[**Location (un) **] syndrome.
   ([1]Koike H, [2]Ito S, [3]Morozumi S, [4]Kawagashira Y, [5]Iijima M,
   [6][**Last Name (un) 5736**] N, [7][**Doctor Last Name 5737**] F, [8]Sobue G.
   Rapidly developing weakness mimicking Guillain-[**Doctor Last Name **]
 syndrome in
   beriberi neuropathy: two case reports.)
    Beriberi would also explain the extremely high lactic acidosis that
   paradoxically rose in setting of fluid resuscitation.
   This would also explain the patient
s primary metabolic acidosis and
   primary respiratory alkalosis.
    ([9][**Doctor Last Name 1526**] MW, [10][**Doctor First Name 612**] J, [11][**Doctor Last Name 1226**] AJ, [12][**Last Name (un) 5746**] E, [13][**Doctor Last Name 3698**]
   M.
   Distinctive acid-base pattern in Wernicke's encephalopathy. [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 5747**]
   Med. [**2189**] [**Month (only) **];50(6):722-5. Epub [**2188**] [**1-6**].
   Hyponatremia: no ascites on exam to suggest cirrhois and portal
   hypertension.  Also patient not overloaded on exam to suggest
   hypervolemic hyponatremia.  Initial thought is hypovolemic hyponatremia
   given relative hypotension and tachycardia vs. euvolumic hyponatremia
   caused by beer potomania. Urine electrolytes are consistent with a low
   FeNA of a hypovolemic state.
   - Bolus with D5NS and recheck lytes.
   AG Metabolic Acidosis: starvation ketosis with lactic acidosis with
   compensated pH. liver disease and alcoholism can lead to a decreased
   utilization of lactic acidosis.
   - Replete with D5 NS
   - calculated osmoles: 268

   Weakness: 3 months of progressive weakness in the setting of alcohol

   Hypophosphatemia
 given the rapid onset, appears to be caused by
   refeeding syndrome. In alcholics, total body hypophosphatemia causes
   exaggerated response to glucose administration. Will replete stores in
   dilute IV form before restarted D5. Not caused by hyperventilation bc

   Assessment and Plan
   39M with weakness and transaminitis, working diagnosis of dry beriberi
   from severe thiamine deficiency.
   .
   PLAN:
   ====
   # Weakness:  Likely due to Neurological beri beri, improving with
   thiamine replacement although seems to have plateaued
   - protecting airway, if desats would get ABG and evaluate for CO2
   retaining
   - continue thiamine and other B vitamins, MVI, folate replacement
   - neuro following, appreciate recs; have low threshold for LP if AMS
   and fever together
   - tachycardia and hyperdynamic heart on echo consistent with beri beri,
   no signs of fluid overload
   - metabolic lactic acidosis has resolved, beri beri explains very high
   initial lactate
   - also would explain respiratory alkalosis
   .
   # Withdrawl:  continue CIWA scale, requiring valium q 2 hrs, seems to
   be improving
   - cont CIWA
   - consider haldol for aggitation
   # Mild Hepatitis: Best etiology appears to be mild alcoholic hepatitis.
   Other differential includes viral, drug mediated, vascular, autoimmine,
   or Wilsons.  Hepatomegaly without splenomegaly suggests early liver
   disease in acute exacerbation in the setting of EtOH. CT suggestive of
   fatty infiltration. Tox screen negative, EtOH level 110.
   - liver team following
   - Viral serologies pending
   - Autoimmune studies pending
   - Ceruloplasmin
   - Social Work Consult
   - Nutrition Consult
   # Hyponatremia: no ascites on exam to suggest cirrhois and portal
   hypertension.  Also patient not overloaded on exam to suggest
   hypervolemic hyponatremia.  Initial thought is hypovolemic hyponatremia
   given relative hypotension and tachycardia vs. euvolumic hyponatremia
   caused by beer potomania. Urine electrolytes are consistent with a low
   FeNA of a hypovolemic state.
   - Bolus with D5NS and recheck lytes.
   # Hypophosphatemia
 given the rapid onset, appears to be caused by
   refeeding syndrome. In alcholics, total body hypophosphatemia causes
   exaggerated response to glucose administration. Will replete stores in
   dilute IV form before restarted D5. Not caused by hyperventilation bc
   nl RR.
   -          will replete aggressively, and hold D5 for now until
   replete.
   # Coagulopathy: likely due to liver failure and poor nutrition. DIC
   also a possibility. Gave Vitamin K 5mg PO X1.
   - elevated hapto, likely has hemolysis, unclear if has [**Name (NI) 5771**] syndrome
   in setting of heavy alcohol use
   - transfuse as neccessary
   #Elevated Lipase: could be from subclinical alcoholic pancreatitis.
   - Will follow, improving
   .
   # HIV status
 per report recent negative result, rechecking, f/u
   results today
   # Access
 2 IVs
   .
   # PPx
 SQ heparin and will start GI ppx
   .
   # FEN
 replacing lytes aggressively, nutrition following, does not
   appear to be in process of a refeeding syndrome
   .
   # Communication
 with patient and mom
   .
   # Code
 full
   .
   # Dispo
 possible call out depending on withdrawl

   Assessment and Plan
   39M with weakness and transaminitis, working diagnosis of dry beriberi
   from severe thiamine deficiency.
   .
   PLAN:
   ====
   # Weakness/ Beriberi:  Likely due to Neurological beri beri, improving
   with thiamine replacement although seems to have plateaued. Does not
   appear infectious, d/c ABx [**3-20**]. No weakness involving diaphragm.
   Unclear whether the prognosis of beriberi is reversible or not given B1
   and nutritional repletion. Metabolic lactic acidosis has resolved, beri
   beri explains very high initial lactate and intial primary respiratory
   alkalosis. HIV neg.
   - continue thiamine and other B vitamins, MVI, folate replacement
   - neuro following, recs to LP, [**3-20**], will consider MRI after further
   discussion with neuro, cannot LP at this time given coagulopathy, will
   consider inpatient EMG
   - tachycardia and hyperdynamic heart on echo consistent with beri beri,
   no signs of fluid overload
   - placed PT/OT consult [**3-21**].
   # [**Month/Year (2) **]:  Using ativan instead of valium since decreased hepatic
   metabolism. Continue CIWA scale with ativan- cont CIWA
   .
   # Vol overload
 appears on CXR and peripheral edema, patient 18L
   positive over course of admission.
   -         giving Lasix 40mg IV BID, goal negative 1L today
   # GIB
 appears to be lower given maroon stools. Patient bit tounge and
   minor mouth bleed. Patient on PPI and patient getting tube feeds
   through NG tube. In setting of coagulopathy.
   -         [**Hospital1 7**] Hct
   -         f/u GI recs
   # Coagulopathy: likely due to liver failure and poor nutrition. DIC
   also a possibility. Gave Vitamin K 5mg PO X1.
    Patient with some blood in mouth from biting tounge, no seizure.
   Patient given 1 u FFP with minimal improvement. Gave vitamin K 10mg IV
   x1 [**3-20**].
   - transfuse as necessary for LP
   #Elevated Lipase: could be from subclinical alcoholic
   pancreatitis. Initial lipase was 117, [**3-21**] is 808. Currently,
   continuing tube feeds.
   - Will trend daily and consider post-pyloric feeding if rising
   # Mild Hepatitis: Best etiology appears to be mild alcoholic hepatitis.
   Other differential includes viral, drug mediated, vascular, autoimmine,
   or Wilsons.  Hepatomegaly without splenomegaly suggests early liver
   disease in acute exacerbation in the setting of EtOH. CT suggestive of
   fatty infiltration. Tox screen negative, EtOH level 110. CMV negative.
   HIV neg.
   - liver team following
   - Viral serologies pending
   - Autoimmune studies pending
   - Ceruloplasmin
   - Social Work Consult
   - Nutrition Consult
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved. No ascites on exam to suggest cirrhois and
   portal hypertension.  Also patient not overloaded on exam to suggest
   hypervolemic hyponatremia.  Initial thought is hypovolemic hyponatremia
   given relative hypotension and tachycardia vs. euvolumic hyponatremia
   caused by beer potomania. Urine electrolytes are consistent with a low
   FeNA of a hypovolemic state.
   # Hypophosphatemia
 Resolved. Given the rapid onset, appears to be
   caused by refeeding syndrome. In alcholics, total body hypophosphatemia
   causes exaggerated response to glucose administration. Will replete
   stores in dilute IV form before restarted D5. Not caused by
   hyperventilation because normal respiratory rate.
   # Access
 2 IVs
   .
   # PPx
 SQ heparin and will start GI ppx
   .
   # FEN
 replacing lytes aggressively, nutrition following, does not
   appear to be in process of a refeeding syndrome
   .
   # Communication
 with patient and mom
   .
   # Code
 full
   .
   # Dispo
 active [**Last Name (LF) 1311**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] continue to monitor in unit

   39 yo male with 25 years of heavy alcohol abuse, presents with several
   months of progressive distal to proximal weakness, now thought to be
   due to wet beri beri, sent to the ICU with worsening MS, fevers, and
   concern for seizure.
   .
   ## AMS: This is worsened in past 2 days. Etiology broad and could
   include infectious, bleed/stroke, metabolic, withdrawal (less likely
   given in hospital for 7 days, though had 65mg diazepam on 13th and 14th
   as well as 10mg diazepam on 15th, 2mg ativan on 15th, and 1mg ativan on
   the 16th, none since). Pt has involuntary shaking and documented eye
   deviation to the left.   These are better today after keppra started.
   LP done [**3-24**] showing no signs of infection at this point, but multiple
   RBCs.  While the tap was traumatic, this is concerning for HSV in
   addition to subarachnoid hemorrhage.  CT on [**3-25**] shows 4mm subdural new
   from [**3-21**].  He also has a UCx from [**3-23**] growing staph, already on
   vanc.  Aspiration pna was also a concern despite CT chest showing no
   consolidation (does show bilateral pleural effusions).  He was started
   on vanc/zosyn/cipro.  Less likely but possible is hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - acyclovir empirically for HSV encephalitis
   - cont infectious workup - f/u cultures, consider tapping pleural
   effusions.
   - continue broad spectrum antibiotics
   - continuous EEG per neuro
   - s/p keppra load, continuing [**Hospital1 7**] keppra dosing
   - conservative CIWA
   - check CK given possible persistent seizures, ? rhabdo (Cr stable)
   - lactulose 30 TID
   .
   # Fever/tachycardia: Together these symptoms are concerning for PE
   especially with episode of hypoxia, however CTA was negative for PE.
   Other concerns include SIRS from infection.  LP NTD from [**3-24**], though
   blood concerning for HSV.  Only cultured source thus far is
   staphylococcus in urine, though other potential sources could be HCV
   encephalitis, pleural effusions.  Withdrawal could also contribute to
   tachycardia, though he is 1 week out from admission (though had 65mg
   diazepam on 13th and 14th as well as 10mg diazepam on 15th, 2mg ativan
   on 15th, and 1mg ativan on the 16th, none since).  Unlikely NMS given
   only had .5 of haldol and 10mg of olanzapine during entire stay.
   - cont antibiotics as above
   - f/u cultures
   - consider tapping pleural effusions
   - CIWA
   - consider CT abd for GI source if no improvement
   .
   ## Respiratory acidosis: likely [**3-7**] sedation from keppra given nl pH
   earlier today.  s/p intubation.
   - wean as tolerated.
   .
   ## subdural hemorrhage: small, 4mm with no midline shift, though could
   contribute to focus for seizure.  Also with coagulopathy, concern is
   for ongoing bleeding.  This is new since the 16th given not evident on
   MRI from [**3-21**].  vit k 10mg IV and FFP given with improvement in INR.
   - repeat CT if changes in mental status, o/w, f/u for resolution in [**4-6**]
   weeks.
   .
   ## pleural effusions: likely compressive atelectasis vs parapneumonic
   effusions, most likely compressive atelectasis with effusions represent
   total body edema.  Still could be infected and source of fevers.
   - consider thoracentesis
   .
   ## Beriberi: Weakness intially improved with thiamine repletion. He has
   components of both wet and dry Beriberi - heart failure, edema and
   weakness.
   - Continue Thiamine, B complex, Multivitamin, folate

   ## Volume status: Peripheral edema, likely due to capillary leak

   A/P: 39 yo male with 25 years of heavy alcohol abuse, presents with
   several months of progressive distal to proximal weakness, now thought
   to be due to wet beri beri, sent to the ICU with worsening MS, fevers,
   and concern for seizure.
   .
   ## AMS: This is worsened in past 2 days. Etiology broad and could
   include infectious, bleed/stroke, metabolic, withdrawal (less likely
   given in hospital for 7 days, though had 65mg diazepam on 13th and 14th
   as well as 10mg diazepam on 15th, 2mg ativan on 15th, and 1mg ativan on
   the 16th, none since). Pt has involuntary shaking and documented eye
   deviation to the left. Neurology consulted on floor and concerned for
   seizure activity.  LP done yesterday showing no signs of infection at
   this point, but multiple RBCs.  While the tap was traumatic, this is
   concerning for HSV in addition to subarachnoid hemorrhage.  He has had
   no head imaging since an MRI head on [**3-21**].  He also has a UCx from [**3-23**]
   growing staph, already on vanc.  Aspiration pna was also a concern
   despite CT chest showing no consolidation (does show bilateral pleural
   effusions).  He was started on vanc/zosyn/cipro.
   - CT head to r/u bleed, embolic event - shows small 4mm subdural.
   - acyclovir empirically for HSV encephalitis
   - cont infectious workup - f/u cultures, consider tapping pleural
   effusions.
   - continue broad spectrum antibiotics, though can likely d/c cipro as
   unsure of any benefit beyond zosyn.
   - continuous EEG per neuro
   - s/p keppra load, continuing [**Hospital1 7**] keppra dosing
   - CIWA
   - check CK given possible persistent seizures, ? rhabdo (Cr stable)
   .
   # Fever/tachycardia: Together these symptoms are concerning for PE
   especially with episode of hypoxia, however CTA was negative for PE.
   Other concerns include SIRS from infection.  LP NTD from [**3-24**], though
   blood concerning for HSV.  Only cultured source thus far is
   staphylococcus in urine, though other potential sources could be HCV
   encephalitis, pleural effusions.  Withdrawal could also contribute to
   tachycardia, though he is 1 week out from admission (though had 65mg
   diazepam on 13th and 14th as well as 10mg diazepam on 15th, 2mg ativan
   on 15th, and 1mg ativan on the 16th, none since).  Unlikely NMS given
   only had .5 of haldol and 10mg of olanzapine during entire stay.
   - cont antibiotics as above
   - f/u cultures
   - consider tapping pleural effusions
   - CIWA
   .
   ## Respiratory acidosis: likely [**3-7**] sedation from keppra given nl pH
   earlier today.  Low threshold to intubate if concern for inability to
   protect airway.
   - serial ABGs
   .
   ## subdural hemorrhage: small, 4mm with no midline shift, though could
   contribute to focus for seizure.  Also with coagulopathy, concern is
   for ongoing bleeding.  This is new since the 16th given not evident on
   MRI from [**3-21**].
   - vit k 10mg IV
   - FFP
   - serial CTs - if enlarging, neurosurgical involvement may be
   necessary.
   .
   ## pleural effusions: likely compressive atelectasis vs parapneumonic
   effusions.  Still could be infected and source of fevers.
   - consider thoracentesis in AM
   .
   ## Beriberi: Weakness intially improved with thiamine repletion. He has
   components of both wet and dry Beriberi - heart failure, edema and
   weakness.
   - Continue Thiamine, B complex, Multivitamin, folate

   39 y/o M with ETOH abuse who presented on [**3-18**] with lactic acidosis,

   hypoxia resolved, and CTA was subsequently negative for PE.  Mental
   status further deteriorated after fevers began and there was concern

   periodic eye deviation.  2mg Ativan given without significant

   700mg IV TID and Keppra 1500mg [**Hospital1 7**].  Neuro attending recommended
   transfer to MICU for continuous EEG monitoring.
   Upon arrival to Micu, he was transported pt to head ct which was + for
   small 4 mm subdural.. Throughout the night, ? r/t keppra dosing pt
   became more somuent, acidotic and o2 dependant. He was intubated at

   A/P: 39 yo male with 25 years of heavy alcohol abuse, presents with
   several months of progressive distal to proximal weakness, now thought

   the 16th, none since). Pt has involuntary shaking and documented eye
   deviation to the left. Neurology consulted on floor and concerned for

   despite CT chest showing no consolidation (does show bilateral pleural

   - CT head to r/u bleed, embolic event - shows small 4mm subdural.
   - acyclovir empirically for HSV encephalitis
   - cont infectious workup - f/u cultures, consider tapping pleural

   - continue broad spectrum antibiotics, though can likely d/c cipro as
   unsure of any benefit beyond zosyn.
   - continuous EEG per neuro

   - CIWA
   - check CK given possible persistent seizures, ? rhabdo (Cr stable)

   # Fever/tachycardia: Together these symptoms are concerning for PE

   Other concerns include SIRS from infection.  LP NTD from [**3-24**], though

 INDICATION:  39-year-old male with altered mental status.  Prior CT
 demonstrated left frontoparietal subdural fluid collection.

 weighted imaging was performed through the brain.  No contrast was
 administered.

 collection in the left frontoparietal region.  This measures up to 4 mm.

 collection, although slightly smaller in size measuring only 2 mm.  There are
 no parenchymal signal abnormalities appreciated, including no evidence of
 hemorrhage, edema, masses, mass effect, or infarction.  The ventricles and
 sulci are normal in size and configuration.  There are no diffusion
 abnormalities detected within the brain parenchyma.  Major vascular flow voids
 are unremarkable.  The orbits are unremarkable.  The paranasal sinuses and
 mastoid air cells are normal.

 collection.  While the exact etiology is unclear, this can be seen in
 meningitis, and correlation is suggested.
 2.  Otherwise normal MR examination of the brain with no evidence for
 hemorrhage, edema, masses, or infarction.

   Assessment and Plan
   39 yo male with 25 years of heavy alcohol abuse, presents with several
   months of progressive distal to proximal weakness, now thought to be
   due to wet beri beri, sent to the ICU with worsening MS, fevers, and
   concern for seizure.
   .
   ## AMS: now improved after keppra dosing,  making seizure more likely.
   Still could be contribution from infection, subdural noted.
   - acyclovir empirically for HSV encephalitis
 d/w with neuro re: d/c
   acyclovir
   - cont infectious workup - f/u cultures, consider tapping pleural
   effusions.
   - continue broad spectrum antibiotics
   - continuous EEG per neuro
 discuss stopping continuous EEG
   - s/p keppra load, continuing [**Hospital1 7**] keppra dosing
   - conservative CIWA
 not requiring
   - d/c lactulose
   .
   # Fever/tachycardia: fever low grade, trended down.  CTA negative for
   PE.
   - cont antibiotics as above
   - f/u cultures
   - consider tapping pleural effusions
   - consider CT abd for GI source if no improvement
   .
   ## Respiratory acidosis: improved after intubations, no successfully
   weaned.
   - extubate
   .
   ## subdural hemorrhage: small, 4mm with no midline shift, though could
   contribute to focus for seizure.  Also with coagulopathy, concern is
   for ongoing bleeding.  This is new since the 16th given not evident on
   MRI from [**3-21**].  vit k 10mg IV and FFP given with improvement in INR.
   - MRI per neuro
 difficulty given continuous EEG.  Leads are
   compatible, but staff unable to disconnect from box.  Either d/c
   continuous EEG as above or need EEG nurse to help with disconnecting
   box from leads
   - f/u MRI
   .
   ## Anemia: up and down since admission. Likely at least partially from
   nutritional issues including b12 deficiency (MCV 101) though also had
   maroon guaiac pos stools during this admission.  No grossly bloody
   stools at this point.
   - guaiac stools
   - recheck in PM
   - further workup if still down this afternoon
   - cont b vitamin supplementation
   ## pleural effusions: likely compressive atelectasis vs parapneumonic
   effusions, most likely compressive atelectasis with effusions represent
   total body edema.  Still could be infected and source of fevers.  Has
   not seemed to directly effect respiratory status
   - consider thoracentesis if no further improvement
   .
   ## Beriberi: Weakness intially improved with thiamine repletion. He has
   components of both wet and dry Beriberi - heart failure, edema and
   weakness.
   - Continue Thiamine, B complex, Multivitamin, folate
   .
   ## Volume status: Peripheral edema, likely due to capillary leak
   syndrome secondary to Beriberi. Also many liters positive over
   admission for tachycardia.  Known pleural effusions.
   - lasix
   - goal negative
   .
   ## GI bleed: Marroon stools during his stay.
   - Guaiac, and monitor Hct.
   .
   ## Coagulopathy:? hepatic contribution, possible component of DIC
   (fibrinogen not low on [**3-21**])  Improvement after FFP and vit k
   - Monitor HCT and transfuse prn Hct <21 (has now gotten 5U RBCs and 2U
   FFP, none since [**2191-3-20**])
   - fibrinogen not suspicious for DIC, ddimer elevated nonspecific
   - guaiac stools
   .
   ## LFT abnormalities: Leading diagnosis is alcoholic hepatitis.  Never
   given steroids.  Stable, not improving.  Slight increased echogenicity
   on RUQ, + ascites, mild splenomegaly.  Has GB sludge.
   - Liver recs (appreciate input)
   - HBV, HIV, HSV, EBV, CMV neg
   - Lactulose discontinued as above
   .
   ## Elevated lipase: Trending down after peak 808. Likely etoh related
   subclinical pancreatitis.
   - follow
   - consider CT abd to eval for inflammation/pseudocyst
   .
   ## FEN/Lytes: Tube feeds, replete lytes prn
   .
   ## Prophylaxis: sc heparin, ppi
   .
   ## Access: PIVs
   .
   ## Code status: FULL CODE
   .

d given HSV PCR negative in CSF

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for acute
   tachycardia/dyspnea in setting of treatment for aspiration pneumonia.
   .
   # Tachypnea: Pt has a large bilateral pleural effusion which is likely
   the main reason for tachypnea. This bilateral pleural effusion, which
   increased in size per most recent imaging, is most probably due to
   heart failure from wet beri-beri, although an occult infectious process
   such as an empyema cannot be excluded.
   - Suspicion of PE: CTA was done last night which showed no PE, although
   limited by motion.
   - Suspicion of pericardial effusion/tamponade physiology (low voltage
   on EKG): Echo showing normal systolic fxn, hyperdynamic. Small
   pericardial effusion.
   - NIF and Vital Capacity attempted to evaluate neuromuscular component
   of tachypnea however pt was unable to tolerate it.
   - A trial of small dose Lasix was undertaken yesterday for gentle
   diuresis (pt responded with 1.5 L UOP in 3 hours)
 no definite
   evidence of improvement in respiratory status, although pt has been
   weaned down to 4L O2 by nasal cannula over the course of the night.
   - Likely, pt is a chronic aspirator and may have a PNA hidden by the
   large pleural effusion. Will continue Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro for empiric
   coverage. Will need thoracentesis for diagnostic and therapeutic
   purposes.
   - Continue nebulizers, serial VBGs to monitor resp status
   .
   # Sinus Tachycardia: hemodynamically stable at this time, pt has been
   adequately volume resuscitated as CVP ranging [**1-16**].
   - Echo neg for tamponade as above.
   - Control pain, fever
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage. Not
   septic as pt maintaining BPs, lactic acid normal, negative cultures to
   date, WBC WNL. Patient had LP previously this hospitalization that
   showed only 2 WBC's, nml protein, nml glucose, and negative HSV pcr. No
   rash or eosinophilia makes suspicion of drug fever lower although in
   still differential.
   - [**Month (only) 51**] need thoracentesis as above.
   - Continue abx as above
   - Suspicion of occult sinusitis given the feeding tube, CT was
   obtained: normal sinuses, no sinusitis
   - Suspicion of occult infectious processes in lungs and abdomen, CT
   torso was obtained: limited by motion, spelnomegaly. 4.6x2.8x2.3 cm
   fluid collection in stomach
   - Suspicion of infectious process in the brain (fluid collection seen

 no definite

   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for acute
   tachycardia/dyspnea in setting of treatment for aspiration pneumonia.
   .
   # Tachypnea: Pt has a large bilateral pleural effusion which is likely
   the main reason for tachypnea. This bilateral pleural effusion, which
   increased in size per most recent imaging, is most probably due to
   heart failure from wet beri-beri, although an occult infectious process
   such as an empyema cannot be excluded.
   - Suspicion of PE: CTA was done last night which showed no PE, although
   limited by motion.
   - Suspicion of pericardial effusion/tamponade physiology (low voltage
   on EKG): Echo showing normal systolic fxn, hyperdynamic. Small
   pericardial effusion.
   - NIF and Vital Capacity attempted to evaluate neuromuscular component
   of tachypnea however pt was unable to tolerate it.
   - A trial of small dose Lasix was undertaken yesterday for gentle
   diuresis (pt responded with 1.5 L UOP in 3 hours)
 no definite
   evidence of improvement in respiratory status, although pt has been
   weaned down to 4L O2 by nasal cannula over the course of the night.
   - Lasix x 1 again today for diuresis since pt is grossly volume
   overloaded
   - Likely, pt is a chronic aspirator and may have a PNA hidden by the
   large pleural effusion. Will continue Vanco/Zosyn/Cipro for empiric
   coverage. Will need bilateral thoracentesis for diagnostic and
   therapeutic purposes. (Will give 2u FFP first to reverse coagulopathy)
   - Continue nebulizers PRN, serial VBGs to monitor resp status
   - Tachycardia likely related to underlying process of fever, infection.
   Hemodynamically stable currently.
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage. Not
   septic as pt maintaining BPs, lactic acid normal, negative cultures to
   date, WBC WNL. Patient had LP previously this hospitalization that
   showed only 2 WBC's, nml protein, nml glucose, and negative HSV pcr. No
   rash or eosinophilia makes suspicion of drug fever lower although in
   still differential.

   - Continue abx as above
   - Suspicion of occult sinusitis given the feeding tube, CT was
   obtained: normal sinuses, no sinusitis

 need to discuss what this is with

                                 FINAL REPORT
 CT CHEST WITHOUT CONTRAST

 REASON FOR EXAM:  39-year-old man with worsening shortness of breath and chest
 x-ray findings, persistently febrile, nose sores, history of wet beriberi
 infiltrative process in lungs.

 TECHNIQUE:  Chest MDCT was performed without contrast using 5-mm and 1.25-mm
 axial slice thickness.  Coronal and sagittal reformations were also obtained.

 FINDINGS:  Since [**2191-4-4**], multifocal consolidation significantly
 increased with dense almost complete consolidation of both lower lobes and
 bilateral fairly symmetric mostly perihilar and peribronchial consolidation in
 both upper lobes and right middle lobe.  Bilateral nonhemorrhagic pleural
 effusions improved, now moderate.

 Prevascular lymph node is unchanged, up to 9 mm.  Other mediastinal lymph
 nodes are scattered but not enlarged using CT criteria.  A nasogastric tube in
 place.  A left PICC ends in the SVC.  Signs of anemia are suggested by
 relative hypodensity of intracardiac blood.  There is no pericardial effusion.

 This study was not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation except to note
 ascites.  There is no bone lesion suspicious for malignancy.

 IMPRESSION:

 1. Worsening bilateral symmetrical mostly perihilar consolidation in both
 upper lobes and right middle lobe, likely due to pulmonary edema. Extensive
 consolidation within both lower lobes could potentially reflect developing
 ARDS. Multifocal rapidly progressing multifocal pneumonia and pulmonary
 hemorrhage are also in the differential.

 2.  Improvement of bilateral nonhemorrhagic pleural effusions, now moderate.

   CXR is somewhat improved this morning and bilateral pleural effusions

   pleural fluid from thoracentesis was transudative.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be a

   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.

 chronic EtOH ingestion,

 so far NGTD

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for acute
   tachycardia/dyspnea, persistent fevers in setting of treatment for
   aspiration pneumonia.
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF this
   am, however, he appears to be more weak peripherally and concern that
   if he were extubated he would tire quickly and require reintubation.
   CXR is somewhat improved this morning and bilateral pleural effusions
   appear improved.   No evidence of underlying infection currently and
   pleural fluid from thoracentesis was transudative.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be a
   central component.
   - BAL for worsening Chest CT findings
 F/U results
 if pos for
   hemosiderin-laden Macros, then check ANCA, anti-basement membrane:
   pathology still pending.  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   - Attempt PSV/CPAP, wean sedation for NIF trial, keep TV low (400cc)
   for poss ARDS
   - Hold Tylenol
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive.  Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease.
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction and
   possible central pontine myelinolysis.
   - central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is okay,
   ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate neuron recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Continue Keppra until outpt f/u with neuron for question of seizure
   activity on the floor
   - Simplify medication list to minimize chance of medications affecting
   mental status
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Now afebrile off all antibiotics,
   could represent drug fever
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach, however not amenable to drainage due to
   location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - will check respiratory virus screen.
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; unlikely since MRI brain did not show any bilateral
   hypothalamic lesions, less likely
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue thiamine repletion
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.  Lasix 40 mg IV x 1
   given 2L positive yesterday.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents
   .
   # Disposition: Pending above, consider trach/PEG if no improvement by

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.
   - Will have Trach/PEG today [**4-11**]
   - BAL done for worsening Chest CT findings
 F/U results
 if pos for
   hemosiderin-laden Macros, pathology still pending.  ANCA and anti-GBM
   ordered and results pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive. Will not increase captopril at this time due to overall
   status.
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is okay,
   ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Consider d/c Keppra for possible drug rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Was afebrile off all antibiotics,
   which could represent drug fever, but now T max 100.5F [**4-11**]
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg x 2
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   hold off on working it up further
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - Consider repeat LP if all the above investigations negative for
   source of fever. However likely low yield, and pt is coagulopathic.
   - Consider paracentesis, although not much ascitic fluid seen by U/S.
   ([**Month (only) 51**] need IR for this)
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   - [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
s a diagnosis of
   exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not show any
   bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Was stable in low 130s. Now improving to mid-130s
   - Highest on differential is SIADH due to pulmonary processes; will
   monitor Na for now and if worsens, do a trial of free water
   restriction.
   - TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP today [**4-11**] prior to trach/PEG)
   - follow Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
   - Consider d/c Keppra
 f/u with Neuro
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian (placed [**4-4**]), A-line, PICC to be placed
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Once Trach/PEG in place, ask case management to start
   screening for placement.
   - Family would like the patient to go to [**Hospital 189**] Rehab once medically
   ready.
   - Need to ask SW or case management to help file long-term disability
   papers.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fevers
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Will attempt trach mask trial
   - Still awaiting BAL results (if pos for hemosiderin-laden Macros,
   pathology still pending).  ANCA and anti-GBM ordered and results
   pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive.
   - stop captopril due to propensity to cause rashes
   - start metoprolol 12.5 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis.
   - potential central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. MRA is
   okay, ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast correction of
   hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
   an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - No need for lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 f/u with Neuro
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics.  Fever last night could represent drug fever.  ID has
   signed off, but will let them know that he is still spiking fevers.
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fever unknown origin
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Cont trach mask trials as tolerated
   - Still awaiting BAL results (if pos for hemosiderin-laden Macros,
   pathology still pending).  ANCA and anti-GBM pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive.
   - Captopril d/c
d due to propensity to cause rashes
   - Increase metoprolol to 25 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**].
   MRA is okay, ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast
   correction of hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs;
   unfortunately, it
s an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - F/u repeat MRI head
   - Cont to hold lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 added to allergy list
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics, wich is c/w drug fever.  ID agrees w/ drug fever.
   **Investigation for infection source so far:
   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   repeat MRI [**4-12**]. [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
   diagnosis of exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not
   show any bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down
   - Surveillance cultures
   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   .
   # Anemia: Pt has many reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness,
   guaiac pos stools. Likely having a very slow GI bleed.  Hct has been
   stable over the last several days.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI changed to qday
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Was stable in low 130s. Now improved to mid
   140s. TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR stable around 2. Likely due to alcoholic liver
   disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this admission.
   - Will need Vit K and FFP before procedures to reverse coagulopathy (2U
   FFP [**4-11**] prior to trach)
   - follow coags/Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: watch for signs of mucosal involvement
 none to date
   - Keppra and captopril stopped
   .
   # Etoh: Outside window for withdrawal.
   - SW consult.
   # FEN: Replete electrolytes, on tube feeds.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt.
   .
   # Access: Left subclavian removed (placed [**4-4**]), A-line to be d/c
   peripheral, PICC not needed, Foley change to condom cath
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Trach in place, Dobhoff until rash resolves. CM and PT
   screen for rehab: [**Hospital 189**] Rehab. Likely this PM or tomorrow. SW
   helping to file long-term disability papers.

   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   team for the key portions of the services provided. I agree with the
   note above, including the assessment and plan. I would emphasize and
   add the following points: 39M EtOH abuse, severe thiamine deficiency,

   Trach placed, PEG on hold due to trunk rash c/w drug reaction. Keppra
   stopped, captopril on hold.
   Exam notable for Tm 100.9 BP 140/70 HR 100-110 RR 22 with sat 100
   on TM 0.4 c ABG 7.5/37/109. Follows commands, remains weak. Bronchial
   BS B. RRR s1s2 hyperdynamic. Soft +BS. 1+ edema. Labs notable for WBC
   9K, HCT 24, K+ 3.9, Cr 0.4. CXR c confluent ASD B.
   Agree with plan to manage respiratory failure with PSV and TM
   trials. Will f/u BAL results while holding antibiotics, and will check
   ANCA/AGBM for component of hemorrhage, though this seems less likely.
   For neuromuscular weakness, will continue to follow NIFs QD, and will
   continue PT/OT evaluation in preparation for rehab. Will advance beta
   blocker for ongoing hypertension and tachycardia. Suspect fevers and
   rash are due to keppra, which we will add to his allergy list. Will f/u
   head MRI read but would hope to avoid any drainage procedures. Continue
   thiamine for beriberi as well as nutritional support via NGT. Continue
   PNBTS, PPI QD, d/c Foley. Needs rehab screening, and will assess for
   PMV today. Remainder of plan as outlined above.

   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Patient with good RSBI and NIF over
   weekend however extubation was not attempted due to pt
s profound
   muscle weakness and concern that he may tire quickly and require
   re-intubation.  Trach placed [**4-11**].
   - Cont trach mask trials as tolerated
   - Still awaiting BAL results (if pos for hemosiderin-laden Macros,
   pathology still pending).  ANCA and anti-GBM pending.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Also starting to become
   hypertensive.
   - Captopril d/c
d due to propensity to cause rashes
   - Increase metoprolol to 25 mg TID and titrate upward as necessary
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion,
   delirium from current acute illness, ICU setting, liver dysfunction,
   dry beri beri and central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**].
   MRA is okay, ruling out ischemic etiology. Likely due to fast
   correction of hyponatremia on admission. Appreciate Neuro recs;
   unfortunately, it
s an irreversible process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs re: prognosis for cognitive recovery, any other
   necessary tests for work up, and the use of zyprexa for discomfort and
   agitation
   - F/u repeat MRI head
   - Cont to hold lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 added to allergy list
   - continue nutritional support

   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem) and was less febrile off all
   antibiotics, wich is c/w drug fever.  ID agrees w/ drug fever.

   - Bronch
 BAL so far unrevealing. F/u on outstanding studies.
   - C. diff neg multiple times
   - fluid collection in stomach seen on imaging, however not amenable to
   drainage due to location.
   - small fluid collection extra-axially on MRI brain; not an abscess;
   repeat MRI [**4-12**]. [**Month (only) 51**] be central (CNS) in etiology, however it
   diagnosis of exclusion; considered unlikely since MRI brain did not
   show any bilateral hypothalamic lesions, however still in differential.
   - pleural fluid labs
 so far NGTD
   - Continue oral hygiene; check for skin break down

   - RSV neg
   - F/u ID, neuro, and neurosurg recs
   .

 none to date

   This is a 39 y/o M w/ wet beri-beri now transferred to ICU for
   persistent tachycardia/dyspnea and fever unknown origin
   .
   # Tachypnea / Respiratory distress: Extubated and trach placed [**4-11**]. CXR
   improved. Stable.
   - Cont trach mask to keep O2 sats > 93%
   - anti-GBM pending
   .
   # Tachycardia: Not fluid responsive. Stable. Likely related to fever,
   cardiomyopathy, and underlying central disease. Is staying
   normotensive. Responding well to metoprolol.
   - Captopril d/c
d due to propensity to cause rashes
   - Continue metoprolol 25 mg TID
   .
   # Altered mental status:  Appears to be improving. Multiple etiologies
 chronic EtOH ingestion, delirium from current acute illness, ICU
   setting, liver dysfunction, dry beri beri and central pontine
   myelinolysis seen MRI brain [**2191-4-5**]. Repeat MRI shows unchanged small
   subdural defect and continued evolution of likely central pontine
   myelinolysis. Likely due to fast correction of hyponatremia on
   admission. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
s an irreversible
   process. Can cause visual problems.
   - Minimize sedating medications. Zyprexa may work better for delirium
   component of his mental status.
   - f/u neuro recs
 will follow up as outpatient
   - Repeat MRI head
 essentially unchanged
   - Cont to hold lactulose as patient is having large amounts of liquid
   diarrhea
   - Keppra stopped as potential cause for rash
 added to allergy list
   - continue nutritional support
   .
   # Fevers: Persistent fevers despite broad spectrum abx coverage (cipro,
   flagyl, vanc, zosyn -> meropenem). Extensive infectious work up all
   negative. Became less febrile off all antibiotics, which is c/w drug
   fever.  ID agrees w/ drug fever.
   .
   # Anemia: Stable HCT at 23-25 over past several days. Pt has many
   reasons to be anemic; malnutrition, illness, guaiac pos stools. Likely
   resolving slow GI bleed.
   - Maintain Hct >21
   - Keep an active type and cross
   - PPI changed to qday
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Resolved.  Was stable in low 130s. Now improved to mid
   140s. TSH WNL and appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim test
   - Trend Na, Cr
   .
   # Beri-Beri: Dry/Wet features, echo hyperdynamic.
   - Continue B vitamins at increased doses, incl thiamine and pyridoxine
   .
   # Coagulopathy: INR normalizing without treatment to 1.7. Likely due to
   alcoholic liver disease and malnutrition. Vit K given during this
   admission. Needs Vit K and FFP prior to invasive procedures.
   - follow coags/Hct.
   .
   # Rash: developed raised, blanchable lesions trunk > extremities [**4-10**]
   - Derm input: likely drug reaction; watch for signs of mucosal
   involvement
 none to date
   - Keppra and captopril stopped for possible drug reaction (Keppra more
   likely to cause rash and fever)
   .
   # FEN: Replete electrolytes, stable on tube feeds.  Has a Dobhoff-
   needs a PEG once truncal rash resolves
   .
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, PPI; PT working with pt
 OOB to chair
   .
   # Access: PIV
   .
   # Code: full
   .
   # Communication: Patient/ Parents.
   .
   # Disposition: Trach in place, Dobhoff until rash resolves then PEG. CM
   working on placement at [**Hospital1 189**]. Discharge once bed becomes available.
   SW helping to file long-term disability papers.

Brief Hospital Course:
Hospital course summary:
Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 39 year old male with ETOH abuse who presented on
[**3-18**] with lactic acidosis, profound weakness and found to be
severely thiamine deficient consistent with a diagnosis of Beri
Beri. He had components of both wet and dry: high output heart
failure, edema and severe weakness.  The patient was repleted
aggressively with Thiamine, a multivitamin, and had an NG placed
for nutrition. He developed refeeding syndrome requiring
agressive electrolyte repletion. He developed ETOH withdrawal
and mental status changes approximately 24-48hr after admission.
He was treated with small doses of benzos and mental status
improved somewhat before he was called out to the general
medicine team on [**3-21**]. Initially, the patient was working with
PT/OT and was evaluated by speech & swallow. On [**3-23**], he was
advanced a dysphagia diet and the following day, he spiked a
fever to 101.8. Initial infectious work up revealed negative UA,
neg Blood Cx, negative Cdiff and possible infiltrate on CXR.
Chest CT revealed bilateral pleural effusions and atelectasis.
Lumbar puncture showed 2 WBCs, RBC 366, glucose 62 and protein
28. The patient was started on Vanc, Zosyn, and Cipro for
possible HAP/Asp PNA. He triggered on [**2191-3-24**] for tachypnea,
tachycardia, and hypoxia. His hypoxia resolved, and CTA was
subsequently negative for PE. Mental status further deteriorated
after fevers began and there was concern for intermittent
seizures due to bilateral upper extremity tremors and periodic
eye deviation. 2mg Ativan was given without significant
improvement. The patient was loaded with Keppra 1gram, started
on empiric Acyclovir 700mg IV TID and Keppra 1500mg [**Hospital1 **]. The
neurology attending recommended transfer to MICU where he had
continuous EEG monitoring.

After Keppra loading the patient became more somnolent and
acidotic and required intubation for airway protection. CT
revealed a small 4mm subdural hematoma but follow up MRI showed
resolution. ABGs improved quickly on the vent and the patient
was easily awakened and extubated on [**3-27**]. He continued to be
dysarthric, have low grade fevers and tachycardia to 90s-110s.
He was continued on Vanc/Zosyn for presumed aspiration pneumonia
but no positive cultures.  The 24hr EEG monitoring was been
discontinued, NGT was removed and the patient was taking some
meds crushed in apple sauce and was advanced to dysphagia diet.

Upon return to the medicine floor, the patient continued to have
fluctuating mental status, occasional tachycardia and
temperatures, presumed to be related to repeated aspiration
pneumonitis. All cultures continued to be negative.  The patient
had a dobhoff tube placed for primary nutrition with tube feeds
and eventually was restarted on pureed oral feeding only when
alert and awake. The patient was again transferred to the ICU
for tachycardia and tachypnea that did not resolve with
non-rebreather treatment, and with fevers to 102F.

## Weakness: On initial presentation the patient was
quadraplegic. With thiamine repletion he improved to extremity
strength of [**4-6**]/5 and plateaued at this strength. He was seen by
PT and OT while in house and discharged to [**Hospital 98**] rehab for
aggressive rehabilitation.

## AMS: When initially hospitalized, pt had been completely
alert and oriented. His mental status then deteriorated and
fluctuated, consistent with delirium. Possibile etiologies are
broad and ultimately much of his mental status changes were
attributed to infection and central pontine myelinolysis. The
considered possibilities included:
1) Aspiration PNA - despite CT chest showing no consolidation
(does show bilateral pleural effusions), the patient completed a
course of Vancomycin and Zosyn. There was concern for repeated
aspiration pneumonitis to explain occasional fevers, tachycardia
and fluctuating mental status.
2) Seizures: The patient was noted to have involuntary upper
extremity shaking and eye deviation to the left. He had multiple
risk factors for seizures (ie cerebellar atrophy) but has had
repeated EEGs without findings consistent with seizure. He was
loaded and maintained on Keppra for several weeks. However,
ultimately keppra was found to be a cause of drug rash and
fevers, and neurology was not highly suspicious of seizure
activity in this patient. Thus keppra was discontinued.
3) Meningitis/encephalitis: In the setting of fever and AMS but
no meningeal signs, the patient had a lumbar puncture which was
inconsistent with bacterial infection or HSV.  Empiric treatment
with broad antibiotics and acyclovir were stopped after
confirmed LP findings.
4) Intracranial bleed or infarct: CT head with 4mm frontal SDH,
but follow up MRI had no sign of bleed. This was thought to be
either artifact or transient SDH secondary to LP in setting of
elevated INR. A repeat MRI did show ongoing small subdural
collection, but per neurology, this was unlikely to be
contributing to the patient's poor mental status. A neurosurgery
consult was obtained, and they did not recommend drainage of
this collection.
5) Withdrawal: The patient was initially treated for withdrawal
but mental status deteriorated after he stopped [**Doctor Last Name **] on the
CIWA scale. Once about 7 days after his last etoh ingestion,
benzos were stopped out of concern for delirium.
6) Wernickes: Deemed unlikely given his initial presention with
normal MS. Also no findings on MRI of mammilary body
abnormality.
7) Hepatic encephalopathy: Given pt's alcohol hepatitis, he was
treated with lactulose and rifaximin for possible contribution
of encephalopathy to altered mental status. Once LFTs returned
to near normal, these meds were stopped, but waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 688**]
mental status persisted.
8) Pellagra: Per case reports, Niacin deficiency in setting of
thiamine repletion has been known to cause altered mental status
and shaking. Pt received niacin repletion via his tube feeds,
which contained 220% of daily niacin requirement.
9) Central Pontine Myelinolysis: Lesion was found on MRI [**2191-4-5**]
in the setting of ongoing altered mental status. An MRA was
obtained to definitively rule out stroke as cause of this
lesion, and MRA was normal. Per neurology, he likely has CPM due
to rapid correction of hyponatremia earler in his hospital
course. CPM is an irreversible process, and neurology consult
attributed his mental status to CPM; however the patient was
quite alert and oriented on the days immediately prior to
discharge, which indicates that he has not suffered an
irreversible insult.

## Respiratory Failure: Upon second transfer to the ICU, the
patient was tachycardic and tachypneic. LENIs were negative for
DVT and suspicion for pulmonary embolus was low. An ECHO was
obtained which showed hyperdynamic systolic function with a
small pericardial effusion and large bilateral pleural
effusions, likely related to his wet Beri-Beri. He was started
on vancomycin/zosyn/ciprofloxacin for presumed  aspiration
pneumonia. He was diuresed with IV lasix boluses and he
underwent needle thoracentesis bilaterally on [**2191-4-5**]. Pleural
fluid was transudative and cultures were negative. The patient
was intubated for tachypnea and fatigue on [**2191-4-7**], likely in the
setting of extreme weakness due to BeriBeri and underwent
bronchoscopy that same day. His airways showed normal anatomy
and mucosa. He had RML and RUL bronchoalveolar lavage, which
returned mildly bloody fluid. This BAL fluid was negative for
infection and hemosiderin-laden macrophages. Ultimately the
patient's antibiotics were discontinued on [**2188-4-5**] because
infectious workup for pneumonia was negative, and these
medications were thought to be contributing to his fevers. He
had a repeat mini-bronchoalveolar lavage on [**4-11**], and again BAL
fluid was negative for infection. The patient underwent
tracheostomy on [**2191-4-11**] and was able to be weaned to trach mask
ventilation on [**2191-4-13**]. He had a Passy-Muir valve placed on [**4-13**]
to enable better speech.

## Fevers: Upon second transfer to ICU, the patient was febrile
and his fevers persisted despite antibiotic therapy and an
extensive infectious work-up. Ultimately, per ID consult, fever
was attributed to medications, and the patient deffervesced when
all antibiotics and keppra were discontinued.  He subsequently
developed low grade fevers several days later which have
continued.  A repeat infectious work-up was negative and his
mental status slowly cleared.  His recurrent fevers are likely
related to his underlying CNS injury and may still have a
medication component.  If the patient develops a fever at rehab,
this is likely due to the above, rather than a new infection,
and should not automatically precipitate transfer back to the
hospital.

## Drug Rash: The patient developed a wide-spread, erythematous,
confluent macular rash on [**4-12**]. A dermatology consult was
obtained, and the rash was attributed to a drug reaction. Keppra
and captopril were thought to be most the likely causes of the
rash, and both were discontinued.  The rash had largely resolved
by the time of discharge, and the patient should be considered
allergic to keppra.

## Coagulopathy: The patient had an elevated PTT and INR thought
to be due to liver dysfunction and severe nutritional
deficiency.  He had no evidence of DIC or active bleeding. He
received Vit K and FFP while in the ICU for possibility of
subdural hematoma and prior to invasive procedures.  He also
received a total of 6 units of pRBCs for Hct <21.

## Volume status: The patient was consistently extravascularly
fluid overloaded, due to hypoalbuminemia from malnutrition,
beriberi related capillary leak, and initial aggressive fluid
resuscitation for tachycardia of unknown source. He was diuresed
with occasional IV lasix until he appeared euvolemic.

## Anemia: The patient was found to have a macrocytic anemia due
to malnutrition and alcohol effects. He was treated with B12 and
folate repletion. His hct has remained stable around 25. He was
also found to have guaiac positive stools. He was maintained on
a PPI and was transfused keep hct >21%.

## Tachycardia: Patient was tachycardic in 110s-120s for much of
his hospital course, likely due to his high-output cardiac
failure from wet BeriBeri and persistent fevers. Ultimately he
was placed on metoprolol with great improvement in his heart
rate to the 90s. Metoprolol 25mg TID should be continued as long
as he remains tachycardic, unless he becomes hypotensive to
SBP<100.

## Hyponatremia: The patient was hyponatremic throughout much of
his hospital stay. Hypothyroidism and adrenal insufficiency were
ruled out as possible etiologies. This was likely due to SIADH
in the setting of multiple pulmonary processes, and his sodium
had corrected by [**2191-4-7**] and has since remained stable.

## LFT abnormalities: On presentation the patient had LFT
abnormalities consistent with alcoholic hepatitis and
pancreatitis. Both improved throughout the admission.

## Nutrition: The patient was given tube feeds via gastric
dobhoff. On the day prior to discharge he had a PEG placed at
the bedside. This PEG can be used for tube feeds starting in the
afternoon of [**4-16**]. This PEG should not be removed until after
[**2191-5-16**].

s an irreversible

 will follow up as outpatient

d due to propensity to cause rashes
   - Continue metoprolol 25 mg TID

 chronic EtOH ingestion, delirium

   beri and central pontine myelinolysis seen MRI which was likely due to

   the same. Appreciate Neuro recs; unfortunately, it
s an irreversible

 will follow up as outpatient
